hints.label: def-epsilon-machine-coarse-graining
hints.title: ε-Machine Coarse-Graining Map
hints.content:
773: :label: def-epsilon-machine-coarse-graining
774: 
775: Given the micro-ε-machine $(\Sigma_\varepsilon, T_\varepsilon)$ for $\{Z_k\}$ and the macro-ε-machine $(\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon)$ for $\{\tilde{Z}_k\}$, define the **projection map**:
776: 
777: $$
778: \pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon \to \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon
779: 
780: $$
781: 
782: by:
783: 
784: $$
785: \pi(\sigma) := \text{causal state of } \mathcal{R}_b(\sigma)
786: 
787: $$
788: 
789: where $\mathcal{R}_b(\sigma)$ means: apply the channel to any representative micro-state $z \in \sigma$, then determine which macro causal state the result belongs to.

hints.label: lem-projection-well-defined
hints.title: Projection Map is Well-Defined
hints.content:
795: :label: lem-projection-well-defined
796: 
797: The projection map $\pi$ is well-defined: if $z, z' \in \sigma$ (same micro causal state), then $\mathcal{R}_b(z)$ and $\mathcal{R}_b(z')$ belong to the same macro causal state.
798: 
799: **Proof:**
800: 
801: **Step 1:** By definition, $z \sim_\varepsilon z'$ means they have identical future distributions:
802: 
803: $$
804: P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z = z) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z = z')
805: 
806: $$
807: 
808: **Step 2:** Apply the channel $\mathcal{R}_b$ to the futures:
809: 
810: $$
811: P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid Z = z) = \int P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid \overrightarrow{Z}) P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid Z = z) d\overrightarrow{Z}
812: 
813: $$
814: 
815: Similarly for $z'$.
816: 
817: **Step 3:** Since $P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z')$, and the channel is deterministic on the macro-level (modulo averaging noise), we have:
818: 
819: $$
820: P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid z) = P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid z')
821: 
822: $$

hints.label: def-computational-closure-rg
hints.title: Computational Closure for RG
hints.content:
830: :label: def-computational-closure-rg
831: 
832: The renormalization transformation $\mathcal{R}_b$ satisfies **computational closure** if the diagram commutes:
833: 
834: $$
835: \begin{array}{ccc}
836: \Sigma_\varepsilon & \xrightarrow{T_\varepsilon} & \Sigma_\varepsilon \\
837: \downarrow \pi & & \downarrow \pi \\
838: \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon & \xrightarrow{\tilde{T}_\varepsilon} & \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon
839: \end{array}
840: 
841: $$
842: 
843: Formally:
844: 
845: $$
846: \pi(T_\varepsilon(\sigma, a)) = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\pi(\sigma), \mathcal{R}_b(a))
847: 
848: $$
849: 
850: for all micro causal states $\sigma$ and observables $a$.
hints.raw_directive:

833:

837: \downarrow \pi & & \downarrow \pi \\
838: \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon & \xrightarrow{\tilde{T}_\varepsilon} & \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon
839: \end{array}
840: 
841: $$
842: 
843: Formally:
844: 
845: $$
846: \pi(T_\varepsilon(\sigma, a)) = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\pi(\sigma), \mathcal{R}_b(a))
847: 
848: $$
849: 
850: for all micro causal states $\sigma$ and observables $a$.

hints.label: thm-computational-closure-sufficient
hints.title: Computational Closure from Lumpability
hints.content:
856: :label: thm-computational-closure-sufficient
857: 
858: **Statement:** If the partition induced by $\mathcal{R}_b$ is strongly lumpable (Definition {prf:ref}`def-strong-lumpability-preliminary`), then computational closure holds.
859: 
860: **Proof:**
861: 
862: **Step 1 (Lumpability implies well-defined projection):** By strong lumpability, for all micro-states $z, z'$ in the same macro-state $\tilde{z}$ (i.e., $\mathcal{R}_b(z) = \mathcal{R}_b(z') = \tilde{z}$), the transition probabilities to any macro-state $\tilde{z}'$ are equal:
863: 
864: $$
865: \int_{z'' : \mathcal{R}_b(z'') = \tilde{z}'} \mathbb{P}(z, dz'') = \int_{z'' : \mathcal{R}_b(z'') = \tilde{z}'} \mathbb{P}(z', dz'')
866: 
867: $$
868: 
869: **Step 2 (Micro causal states refine macro-partition):** Suppose $z, z'$ are in the same micro-causal state: $P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z')$. We must show they map to the same macro-causal state.
870: 
871: Applying the channel to both sides:
872: 
873: $$
874: P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid z) = \int P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid \overrightarrow{Z}) P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z) d\overrightarrow{Z}
875: 
876: $$
877: 
878: Since $P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z) = P(\overrightarrow{Z} \mid z')$ and the channel $\mathcal{R}_b$ is the same for both:
879: 
880: $$
881: P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid z) = P(\overrightarrow{\tilde{Z}} \mid z')
882: 
883: $$
884: 
885: Therefore, $\mathcal{R}_b(z)$ and $\mathcal{R}_b(z')$ have identical macro-futures, hence are in the same macro-causal state. The projection $\pi: \Sigma_\varepsilon \to \tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon$ is well-defined.
886: 
887: **Step 3 (Commutation diagram):** We must verify $\pi \circ T_\varepsilon = \tilde{T}_\varepsilon \circ \pi$.
888: 
889: Consider a micro-causal state $\sigma$ and an observable $a$. The micro-transition is:
890: 
891: $$
892: T_\varepsilon(\sigma' \mid \sigma, a) = \int_{z \in \sigma} \int_{z' \in \sigma'} \mathbb{P}(z, dz') \cdot \mathbb{1}_{o(z')=a} \cdot \frac{d\mu_{\text{QSD}}(z)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}
893: 
894: $$
895: 
896: Applying $\pi$ to the result means determining which macro-causal state $\sigma'$ maps to.
897: 
898: The macro-transition is:
899: 
900: $$
901: \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\tilde{\sigma}' \mid \tilde{\sigma}, \tilde{a}) = \int_{\tilde{z} \in \tilde{\sigma}} \int_{\tilde{z}' \in \tilde{\sigma}'} \tilde{\mathbb{P}}(\tilde{z}, d\tilde{z}') \cdot \mathbb{1}_{\tilde{o}(\tilde{z}')=\tilde{a}} \cdot \frac{d\tilde{\mu}_{\text{QSD}}(\tilde{z})}{\tilde{\mu}_{\text{QSD}}(\tilde{\sigma})}
902: 
903: $$
904: 
905: **Step 4 (Kernel push-forward):** By lumpability, the macro-kernel is the lumped version of the micro-kernel:
906: 
907: $$
908: \tilde{\mathbb{P}}(\tilde{z}, \tilde{z}') = \sum_{\sigma: \pi(\sigma) = \tilde{z}} \sum_{\sigma': \pi(\sigma') = \tilde{z}'} \int_{z \in \sigma} \int_{z' \in \sigma'} \mathbb{P}(z, dz') \cdot \frac{d\mu_{\text{QSD}}(z)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}
909: 
910: $$
911: 
912: This is well-defined by lumpability (independent of choice of $z \in \sigma$).
913: 
914: **Step 5 (Commutation):** Substituting the lumped kernel into the macro-transition formula and simplifying yields:
915: 
916: $$
917: \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\pi(\sigma'), \tilde{a}) = \pi(T_\varepsilon(\sigma', a))
918: 
919: $$
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-157
hints.title: Avoidance of Pseudo-Inverses
hints.content:
925: :class: note
926: 
927: **Why we avoid $\mathcal{R}_b^{-1}$:** The original formulation "$\tilde{\mathbb{P}} = \mathcal{R}_b \circ \mathbb{P} \circ \mathcal{R}_b^{-1}$" is problematic because:
928: 
929: 1. $\mathcal{R}_b$ is not invertible (many-to-one map)
930: 2. Even defining a "disintegration" or "pseudo-inverse" requires choosing a conditional measure $P(Z \mid \tilde{Z})$, which is not canonical
931: 3. The formula obscures the actual requirement: **lumpability**

hints.label: thm-lumpability-closure-equivalence
hints.title: Equivalence of Strong Lumpability and Computational Closure
hints.content:
937: :label: thm-lumpability-closure-equivalence
938: 
939: For the renormalization map $\mathcal{R}_b: \Omega \to \tilde{\Omega}$ and BAOAB transition kernel $\mathbb{P}$, the following are equivalent:
940: 
941: 1. The partition induced by $\mathcal{R}_b$ is **strongly lumpable** with respect to $\mathbb{P}$
942: 2. The renormalization transformation satisfies **computational closure**
943: 
944: **Proof:**
945: 
946: $(1 \Rightarrow 2)$: This is Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-computational-closure-sufficient`.
947: 
948: $(2 \Rightarrow 1)$: This is Proposition {prf:ref}`prop-closure-implies-lumpability` (§7.1).

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-186
hints.title: Significance of the Equivalence
hints.content:
954: :class: note
955: 
956: **This equivalence is a central result of the framework.** It establishes that:
957: 
958: - **Computational closure** (an information-theoretic property about predictive models) is **mathematically equivalent to**
959: - **Strong lumpability** (a measure-theoretic property of Markov chains)
960: 
961: **Implications:**
962: 
963: 1. **Unification**: Two seemingly distinct concepts from different fields (computational mechanics vs. stochastic processes) are revealed to be the same.
964: 
965: 2. **Dual characterization**: We can prove closure either by:
966:    - Showing the macro-ε-machine is a coarse-graining of the micro-ε-machine (computational mechanics approach)
967:    - Showing transition probabilities factor through partition classes (Markov chain approach)
968: 
969: 3. **RG interpretation**: Renormalization group flow preserves predictive power **if and only if** the coarse-graining is lumpable.

hints.label: def-parametrized-epsilon-machine
hints.title: Parametrized ε-Machine Family
hints.content:
979: :label: def-parametrized-epsilon-machine
980: 
981: A **parametrized family** of ε-machines is a collection $\{(\Sigma_\varepsilon(g), T_\varepsilon(g))\}_{g \in \mathcal{G}}$ indexed by parameters $g = (g_1, \ldots, g_m) \in \mathcal{G}$.
982: 
983: For the Fractal Gas:
984: - $g$ includes coupling constants (gauge coupling, cloning noise scale, friction, etc.)
hints.raw_directive:
976: The key insight: the RG beta function describes how the **parameters of the ε-machine** evolve under coarse-graining.
977: 
978: :::{prf:definition} Parametrized ε-Machine Family
979: :label: def-parametrized-epsilon-machine
980: 
981: A **parametrized family** of ε-machines is a collection $\{(\Sigma_\varepsilon(g), T_\varepsilon(g))\}_{g \in \mathcal{G}}$ indexed by parameters $g = (g_1, \ldots, g_m) \in \mathcal{G}$.
982: 
983: For the Fractal Gas:
984: - $g$ includes coupling constants (gauge coupling, cloning noise scale, friction, etc.)
985: - The lattice spacing $a$ is an implicit parameter

hints.label: thm-rg-flow-epsilon-machine
hints.title: RG Flow as ε-Machine Parameter Flow
hints.content:
990: :label: thm-rg-flow-epsilon-machine
991: 
992: Let $\mathcal{R}_b$ be the block-spin channel with block size $b$ (lattice spacing $a \to ba$). Define the **RG flow** $\mathcal{RG}_b: \mathcal{G} \to \mathcal{G}$ by:
993: 
994: $$
995: g' = \mathcal{RG}_b(g)
996: 
997: $$
998: 
999: where $g'$ is the set of parameters such that:
1000: 
1001: $$
1002: (\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon) = (\Sigma_\varepsilon(g'), T_\varepsilon(g'))
1003: 
1004: $$
1005: 
1006: (the macro-ε-machine at spacing $ba$ equals the ε-machine with parameters $g'$).
1007: 
1008: **Continuum limit:** Taking $b = e^{\delta t}$ for infinitesimal $\delta t$, the **beta function** is:
1009: 
1010: $$
1011: \beta(g) := \lim_{\delta t \to 0} \frac{\mathcal{RG}_{e^{\delta t}}(g) - g}{\delta t} = \frac{dg}{d\log a}
1012: 
1013: $$
1014: 
1015: **Proof:**
1016: 
1017: **Step 1:** By computational closure (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-computational-closure-sufficient`), the macro-ε-machine is a coarse-graining of the micro-ε-machine.
1018: 
1019: **Step 2:** The parameters $g'$ are determined by matching the macro-transition probabilities. By the lumped kernel formula (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-computational-closure-sufficient`, Step 4):
1020: 
1021: $$
1022: \tilde{T}_\varepsilon(\tilde{\sigma}' \mid \tilde{\sigma}, \tilde{a}; g') = \sum_{\sigma \in \pi^{-1}(\tilde{\sigma})} \frac{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\pi^{-1}(\tilde{\sigma}))} \sum_{\sigma' \in \pi^{-1}(\tilde{\sigma}')} T_\varepsilon(\sigma' \mid \sigma, a; g)
1023: 
1024: $$
1025: 
1026: where $\frac{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\sigma)}{\mu_{\text{QSD}}(\pi^{-1}(\tilde{\sigma}))}$ is the conditional probability weight (fraction of QSD mass in macro-state $\tilde{\sigma}$ that resides in micro-causal-state $\sigma$).
1027: 
1028: **Step 3:** For the Fractal Gas, the transition probabilities are determined by the BAOAB kernel, which depends on $g = (g_{\text{gauge}}, \gamma, \sigma, \ldots)$.
1029: 
1030: **Step 4:** Solving for $g'$ such that the macro-kernel matches the parametrized form yields the RG flow.

hints.label: cor-beta-function-lattice-qft
hints.title: Beta Function from Lattice QFT
hints.content:
1036: :label: cor-beta-function-lattice-qft
1037: 
1038: For the gauge coupling $g_{\text{gauge}}$ in the Fractal Gas lattice QFT (§ 9.5 of [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)), the beta function derived from computational closure matches the one-loop perturbative result:
1039: 
1040: $$
1041: \beta(g) = -\frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} \cdot \frac{11N_c - 2N_f}{3} + O(g^5)
1042:

hints.title: Assumption of Renormalizability
hints.content:
1049: :class: warning
1050: 
1051: **Critical assumption in Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-rg-flow-epsilon-machine`:** We assume that the macro-ε-machine $(\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon)$ can be written in the same parametric form as the micro-ε-machine, i.e., $(\tilde{\Sigma}_\varepsilon, \tilde{T}_\varepsilon) = (\Sigma_\varepsilon(g'), T_\varepsilon(g'))$ for some $g' \in \mathcal{G}$.
1052: 
1053: This is the **definition of renormalizability**: a theory is renormalizable if coarse-graining produces a new theory within the same functional class, differing only in parameter values.
1054: 
1055: **Two approaches:**
1056: 
1057: 1. **Assume renormalizability a priori** (as we do here). This is justified for theories known to be renormalizable (e.g., non-Abelian gauge theories). The existence of $g'$ is then a modeling assumption, validated by the success of RG methods.
1058: 
1059: 2. **Prove renormalizability from first principles**. This requires showing that the block-spin channel $\mathcal{R}_b$ applied to a BAOAB kernel with parameters $g$ yields a new BAOAB kernel with parameters $g'$. This is technically challenging and requires detailed analysis of the Wilson action structure (partially done in § 9.5 of [08_lattice_qft_framework.md](08_lattice_qft_framework.md)).
1060: 
1061: **Current status:** We assume renormalizability and demonstrate its consequences. Proving it rigorously from the Fractal Set dynamics is left to future work.
